acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.72mg/L of the crustacea (Mysid) (AQUIRE (2008)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Since LD50 value of the dermal administration test employing rabbits was >2 g/kg (2,000 mg/kg) (HSDB (2002)), it was classified into "Not classified".

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Saturated vapor pressure level of this substance (25degC)is 1.18 ppm (0.01 mg/L). Since LC50 value with 0.32 mg/L of the 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats (HSDB (2008)) was larger than saturated vapor pressure level, it was classified into Category 2 by applying the dust standard.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Since it was a solid by the definition of GHS and inhalation in gas was not assumed, it was classified into "Not applicable".

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: From a description of LD50 value of 235 mg/kg (male) and 178 mg/kg (female), (HSDB (2002)) in the oral administration test employing rats, it was classified into Category 3.

aspiration_hazard.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

carcinogenicity.rationale: Since no evaluation by major international evaluation agencies is made and there is no data, classification is not possible.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and there were no rapid degradability (not readily degradable, the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data (2008))), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

organic_peroxides.rationale: The organic compound not including peroxy group in molecule.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Although it is an organic compound including oxygen, not fluorine and chlorine, this oxygen has not chemically bound to any elements other than carbon and hydrogen.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: There is a description as follows in the developmental toxicity study via oral administration using rabbits of 7-19 day pregnancy, " Delayed ossification was observed in the skeletal element of a few fetuses at the dose level where general toxicity is not expressed" (HSDB (2008). Effect is nothing but "delayed ossification." Classification is not possible, because information is from the information source, List 2 and data related with female and male reproductive functions are not available.

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Classification is not possible since there is no data.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: It has been described that "there is severe damage to a corneal, no recoverability, and it is corrosive" (HSDB (2002)) in the eye irritation test employing rabbits. Moreover, it has been described as "Severe" (RTECS (2008)) in the standard Draize test employing rabbits. As mentioned above, it was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: There are descriptions, "Administration of 0.5g caused erythema followed by exfoliation and edema" (HSDB (2008)) in the 4 hour skin irritation test with rabbits and "moderate to severe" in the cited literature (USEPA, Reregistration Eligibility Desision Document). Moreover, there is a description , "Severe" (RTECS (2008)) in the standard Draize test with rabbits. It was classified in Category 2.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Although it has been described that "this substance is weak sensitizer" in the skin sensitization test employing guinea pig (HSDB (2002)), classification is not possible because of unknown number of animals being positive.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At) are not included.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (systemic toxicity)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It is written in 90-day oral administration test in rats that "there were some dyspnea, weight loss was found in those animals, and some were died" (HSDB (2002)) within the scope of the guidance value of Category 2. Since the organ could not be specified, it was classified into Category 2 (systemic toxicity). In addition, it is written in 90-day dermal administration test in rats that "there was decrease in triglyceride level in males, and rise in alkaline phosphatase and chlorine ion as well as decrease in cholesterol in females" outside the scope of the guidance value of Category 2 (HSDB (2002)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data
